intro: Lithospermum virginianum, commonly known as Virginia rock pepper, is a perennial flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, erect stems and blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in open woodlands or along stream banks. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slightly serrated edge. The fruit is a capsule that releases small, dark seeds when mature.
